channel.title: Questions
channel.description:
1.[b]How can i know wich one to use[/b] writeWord OR writeByte OR writeString and you know all the stream class methods. 2.Only if you can explain because i didn't found something about this: what this means ">>" in java
Another question if ill add a new case into the server packets method lets say money pouch and then ill want to use that case in another method can i do in that method createFrame(moneyPouchCaseID); ? and how can i know what to use (inStream./outStream.) Really thank you for helping me understand this.

item.title: Questions
item.dc:creator: @Sup22211 Sup22211
item.description:
@Sup22211 wrote:

Yes, thank you very much Now i know how to use a new packet into my methods. ;D

Read full topic

item.title: Questions
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Sup22211:

(case 323: for example)

Read my link about primitive data types. The packet id is an unsigned byte, so it can be values 0 to 255.

[quote=“Sup22211, post:3, topic:517707”]Thank you very much bro but my main question was the 3 one
{
Another question if ill add a new case into the server packets method lets say money pouch and then ill want to use that case in another method can i do in that method
createFrame(moneyPouchCaseID); ?[/quote]
Yes.

Sup22211:

and how can i know what to use (inStream./outStream.)

I don’t think you understand anything about data streams. In would be data coming to the client, out would be data going to the server.

Read full topic

item.title: Questions
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Primitive data type

In computer science, primitive data type is either of the following:[citation needed] In most programming languages, all basic data types are built-in. In addition, many languages also provide a set of composite data types. Opinions vary as to whether a built-in type that is composite should be considered "primitive".[citation needed] Depending on the language and its implementation, primitive data types may or may not have a one-to-one correspondence with objects in the computer's memory. Howeve...


You can use whatever you want, just make sure they are the same on both sides.

is the signed right shift operator.
http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/op3.html

Read full topic
